prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Legal Basis for a Claim for Damages

para.paratext: Where an action is based on breach of contract, the defendant's obligations are as expressly or impliedly set out in the contract, and general contract principles also apply. The plaintiff must show that the defendant's breach caused loss and that such a loss was within the contemplation of the parties at the time the contract was entered into.[1] It is not open to the defendant to claim that the acts of a third party induced the breach. The plaintiff is, however, wise to include in its claim both the defendant wrongdoer and any party that induced a breach.

If clients of the wrongdoer testify that they were going to take their business away from the moving party in any event, the plaintiff may have suffered only nominal damages. Similarly, if the wrongdoer unsuccessfully attempted to solicit a client of the plaintiff's, the plaintiff may have suffered no loss and will only be awarded nominal damages. The moving party, in order to receive greater than nominal damages, must be able to convince the court that it suffered loss as a result of the wrongdoer's activities or as a result of the loss of opportunity to do new work for a prospective client.[2]
The relevant date for assessment of damages is usually the time of breach, although another time may be chosen if that were more just.[3]

Faccenda Chicken Ltd. v. Fowler, [1986] 1 All E.R. 617 (C.A.), at p. 625. See also RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. (2003), 55 C.C.E.L. (3d) 179 (B.C.S.C.), supp. reasons 55 C.C.E.L. (3d) 208 (B.C.S.C.), appeal allowed in part 275 D.L.R. (4th) 385 (B.C.C.A.), appeal allowed in part 298 D.L.R. (4th) 1 (S.C.C.).
Sanders v. Parry, [1967] 1 W.L.R. 753 (Q.B.); See also Robb v. Green, [1895] 2 Q.B. 1, per Hawkins J.
